commands/registry.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /**
00002  * @file commands/registry.h
00003  *
00004  * A registry which allows to add, remove and get pointers to Command like
00005  * functions using a given name as identifier. This data structure is mainly
00006  * used by the dispatcher to store all the known commands and retrieve them by
00007  * name.
00008  */
00009 
00010 
00011 #pragma once
00012 
00013 
00014 /**
00015  * The interface which all functions used as commands have to implement.
00016  * The interface is similar to the required prototype for the \c main method; it
00017  * takes an \a argc argument indicating the number of arguments and an \c argv
00018  * argument which points to an array of strings, already splitted by the command
00019  * parser. The function must return 0 if completed successfully or a custom
00020  * positive error code if it fails.
00021  */
00022 typedef int (* Command) (int argc, const char * argv[]);
00023 
00024 
00025 /**
00026  * Adds a given command to the commands registry using the given name.
00027  * If a command was already registered with the same name, it is overwritten.
00028  *
00029  * @param[in] name  The string indicating the name to use to identify the
00030  *                  command.
00031  * @param[in] cmd   The pointer to the command function to register under the
00032  *                  given name.
00033  *
00034  * @return  0 if the value was read correctly, a negative error code otherwise.
00035  */
00036 int command_registry_register(const char * name, Command cmd);
00037 
00038 
00039 /**
00040  * Removes the command identified by the given name from the command registry.
00041  *
00042  * @param[in] name  The string indicating the name of the command to remove.
00043  *
00044  * @return  0 if the command was removed correctly, 1 if it was not found and a
00045  *          negative error code if an error occurred.
00046  */
00047 int command_registry_unregister(const char * name);
00048 
00049 
00050 /**
00051  * Retrieves and returns the command identified by the given name.
00052  *
00053  * @param[in] name  The string indicating the name of the command to retrieve.
00054  *
00055  * @return  The command if a value existed for the key name, NULL otherwise.
00056  */
00057 Command command_registry_get(const char * name);
